root.text: When I think about ways to "make programming easier", I often find myself thinking about the same small set of end-user problems that I'd like to be easier to solve. I'd love to hear whether you also have scenarios like these in your head that you use to evaluate your ideas.

elements.text: When I think about ways to "make programming easier", I often find myself thinking about the same small set of end-user problems that I'd like to be easier to solve. I'd love to hear whether you also have scenarios like these in your head that you use to evaluate your ideas.

text:
<@UAL7940NM> I like your question a lot. Don’t really have a good answer for it, but wanted to mention that my impression is that we all tend to try to build a big solution for better programming. That often leads to us being interested in what others do on the surface, but it rarely happens that our visions align enough so that we start collaborating (I tried to make that a little more explicit with my earlier effort to find shared principles for this group).

I wish it would be easier for us to extract smaller problems that we all have to solve on the way to a holistic solution, and maybe increase the chance of collaboration a little. I feel like we have built an awesome community of very capable individuals here that could pull off amazing things, if we can find ways to make us more than just the sum of the parts.

We should still all keep working on individual projects — diversity of ideas is very important in a space where we are mostly exploring. However, identifying the bits where more of us struggle with a concrete albeit smaller problem could tap into our collective power to solve it quicker or better or both.

Smaller artifacts like an explorable explanation of a concept more of us need to solve for their own projects could be a great way to collaborate for a defined amount of time and get some sense of achievement at the same time, which I’m sure will also have positive impact on our individual projects.

Of course, a first step in that direction would be to better understand what each of us are working on currently, and what some of the (smaller) research questions are we currently think about and maybe also make that information a little easier to find.

text:
My explorable of the Hough Transform is now online: <https://fkohlgrueber.github.io/blog/hough-transform/>
Feedback is highly appreciated :wink:

elements.text: My explorable of the Hough Transform is now online:

text:
Cool! Some random notes:

• I didn't get a good sense of the *purpose* of this algorithm at the start - what problem it's supposed to solve. (I guess it's edge detection...?) Don't be afraid of more words :slightly_smiling_face:
• I also would appreciate some intuition/analogy in words at the start of how/why the algorithm works. I love this method of organizing explanations <https://betterexplained.com/articles/adept-method/>
• I would consider putting the your first interactive visualization at the end as opposed to the beginning of the article. If the point of the algorithm is edge detection, it's hard to see that in placing single points. Maybe that interactive has more to do with *how* the algorithm works, while the interactive at the end shows the result of the algorithm.
• It would be neat in the last interactive viz if you could moreover the graph and it would show you the point in the diagram. Even better if it as was connected to the original picture!

root.text:
I was just spending some time going through some of your blogs adding many of you to my feed reader.
Now I wonder: Is there an easy way to have all the posts that members of this Slack group post automatically go into a #publications channel? Some hack that involves RSS and a bot or Slack integration? I don’t know much about Slack, but maybe someone here does. I’d love to have a single place where I can hear about all you great people writing interesting stuff into the internet.

text:
Yeah, about that… the categories in my feed reader don't quite align with what we discuss here. I didn't even have a "Future of Programming" category in there. Until just now. I quickly went through most of my feeds and marked some as relevant for here. I might have missed some, and I might have added strange ones. Happy to hear what you think.

Oh, thanks <@UA8HY8R7B> for posting your list. Not only is it a great list, it also made me aware that I can just quickly share an OPML file. So here we go: <https://gist.github.com/stefanlesser/ced758cee6bb5105c9d259d6edfb15cf>

text: Hi Steve, thanks for the detailed feedback! I did indeed focus on the interactive diagrams and only spent half an hour or so on the text. You're right that there's barely any description of how the hough transform works or why it's useful/necessary. I should definitely improve on that. Changing the order of the diagrams is a good idea, I'll try that too. I'm not sure I understood your last point, could you explain that again? Thanks :wink:

text: Great question, <@UAL7940NM>. There are definitely scenarios I think about, though it's not a small set but is ever-growing. My ongoing struggle is usually to reduce the set to the more general, broader problems. I'm approaching this from the POV that almost all concepts in computed are 'constructions/inventions' and if we start by rejecting them all, what is the set of concepts that we could introduce that would not lead to the kinds of problems we currently have. (Rejecting is easy but forgetting is hard). I think attacking the 'problem' at all levels is useful.

elements.text: Great question,

. There are definitely scenarios I think about, though it's not a small set but is ever-growing. My ongoing struggle is usually to reduce the set to the more general, broader problems. I'm approaching this from the POV that almost all concepts in computed are 'constructions/inventions' and if we start by rejecting them all, what is the set of concepts that we could introduce that would not lead to the kinds of problems we currently have. (Rejecting is easy but forgetting is hard). I think attacking the 'problem' at all levels is useful.

text: <@U8A5MS6R1> thanks for your response. Reducing concrete examples to general problems is hard, especially because all of us are biased towards what we think might be important. Maybe we can all benefit from sharing our scenarios and derive principles from a more diverse set of use cases. What do you think?

elements.text: thanks for your response. Reducing concrete examples to general problems is hard, especially because all of us are biased towards what we think might be important. text: We could start in a separate channel and if we find it too limiting, we can copy the content to a more appropriate place. This would be the least effort to get started and if this idea doesn't work out, it's not much time wasted.
